title: Varying Coefficient Meta-Analysis
text: Implements functions varying coefficient meta-analysis methods. methods assume effect size homogeneity. Subgroup effect size comparisons, general linear effect size contrasts, linear models effect sizes based varying coefficient methods can used describe effect size heterogeneity. Varying coefficient meta-analysis methods require unrealistic assumptions traditional fixed-effect random-effects meta-analysis methods.

what: Confidence interval for an average effect size using a random coefficient model — meta.ave.gen.rc
title: Confidence interval for an average effect size using a random coefficient model — meta.ave.gen.rc
text: Computes estimate, standard error, confidence interval weighted average effect multiple studies using random coefficient (random-effects) meta-analysis model. estimate effect-sze heterogeneity (tau-squared) also computed. random coefficient model assumes studies meta-analysis random sample definable superpopulation studies. assumption difficult justify. weighted average estimate biased regardless number studies sample size per study actual confidence interval coverage probability can much smaller specified confidence level effect sizes correlated weights. method also assume true effects sizes superpopulation studies normal distribution. large number studies, large sample size, required assess superpopulation normality assumption accurately estimate tau-squared. traditional confidence interval population tau-squared hypersensitive minor difficult detect violations superpopulation normality assumption.

what: Confidence interval for an average point-biserial correlation — meta.ave.pbcor
title: Confidence interval for an average point-biserial correlation — meta.ave.pbcor
text: Computes estimate, standard error, confidence interval average point-biserial correlation two studies. Two types point-biserial correlations can meta-analyzed. One type uses unweighted variance appropriate 2-group experimental designs. type uses weighted variance appropriate 2-group nonexperimental designs simple random sampling within group. function requires point-biserial correlations type.  Use meta.ave.gen function meta-analyze combination biserial correlation types.

title: Confidence interval for an average point-biserial correlation — meta.ave.pbcor
code: meta.ave.pbcor(alpha, m1, m2, sd1, sd2, n1, n2, type, bystudy = TRUE)

text: alpha alpha level 1-alpha confidence m1 vector estimated means group 1 m2 vector estimated means group 2 sd1 vector estimated SDs group 1 sd2 vector estimated SDs group 2 n1 vector group 1 sample sizes n2 vector group 2 sample sizes type set 1 weighted variance set 2 unweighted variance bystudy logical also return study estimate (TRUE)

title: Confidence interval for an average point-biserial correlation — meta.ave.pbcor
text: Returns matrix.  first row average estimate across studies.  bystudy true, 1 additional row study.  matrix following columns: Estimate - estimated effect size SE - standard error LL - lower limit confidence interval UL - upper limit confidence interval

what: Forest plot for average effect sizes — meta.ave.plot
title: Forest plot for average effect sizes — meta.ave.plot
text: Generates forest plot visualize effect sizes estimates overall averages meta.ave functions vcmeta.  column exp(Estimate) present, function plots exponentiated effect size CI found columns exp(Estimate), exp(LL), exp(UL). Otherwise, function plots effect size CI found columns Estimate, LL, UL.

title: Forest plot for average effect sizes — meta.ave.plot
code: meta.ave.plot(   result,   reference_line = NULL,   diamond_height = 0.2,   ggtheme = ggplot2::theme_classic() )

title: Forest plot for average effect sizes — meta.ave.plot
text: result result matrix replicate functions vcmeta reference_line Optional x-value reference line.  applies focuse 'Difference' ''.  Defaults NULL, case reference line drawn. diamond_height Optional height diamond representing average effect size. applies focus 'Average' ''. Defaults 0.2 ggtheme optional ggplot2 theme object; defaults theme_classic()

title: Forest plot for average effect sizes — meta.ave.plot
text: Returns ggplot object.  stored, can customized via ggplot API

title: Forest plot for average effect sizes — meta.ave.plot
code: # Plot results from meta.ave.mean2 m1 <- c(7.4, 6.9) m2 <- c(6.3, 5.7) sd1 <- c(1.72, 1.53) sd2 <- c(2.35, 2.04) n1 <- c(40, 60) n2 <- c(40, 60) result <- meta.ave.mean2(.05, m1, m2, sd1, sd2, n1, n2, bystudy = TRUE) meta.ave.plot(result, reference_line = 0)    # Plot results from meta.ave.meanratio2 # Note that this plots the exponentiated effect size and CI m1 <- c(53, 60, 53, 57) m2 <- c(55, 62, 58, 61) sd1 <- c(4.1, 4.2, 4.5, 4.0) sd2 <- c(4.2, 4.7, 4.9, 4.8) cor <- c(.7, .7, .8, .85) n <- c(30, 50, 30, 70) result <- meta.ave.meanratio.ps(.05, m1, m2, sd1, sd2, cor, n, bystudy = TRUE) myplot <- meta.ave.plot(result, reference_line = 1) myplot   # Change x-scale to log2 library(ggplot2) myplot <- myplot + scale_x_continuous(   trans = 'log2',    limits = c(0.75, 1.25),    name = "Estimated Ratio of Means, Log2 Scale" ) myplot

Defaults 0.2 difference_axis_ticks Optional requested number ticks difference axis.  applies focus 'Difference' ''. Defaults 5. ggtheme optional ggplot2 theme object; defaults theme_classic()

title: Plot to compare estimates from an original and follow-up study — replicate.plot
text: Returns ggplot object.  stored, can customized via ggplot API

title: Plot to compare estimates from an original and follow-up study — replicate.plot
code: # Compare Damisch et al., 2010 to Calin-Jageman & Caldwell 2014 # Damisch et al., 2010, Exp 1, German participants made 10 mini-golf putts #  Half were told they had a 'lucky' golf ball; half were not #  Found a large but uncertain improvement in shots made in the luck condition # Calin-Jageman & Caldwell, 2014, Exp 1, was a pre-registered replication with #  input from Damisch, though with English-speaking participants # # Here we compare the effect sizes, in original units,for the two studies # Use the replicate.mean2 function because the design is 2-group between-subs  library(ggplot2) damisch_v_calinjageman_raw <- replicate.mean2(   alpha = 0.05,   m11 = 6.42,   m12 = 4.75,   sd11 = 1.88,   sd12 = 2.15,   n11 = 14,   n12 = 14,   m21 = 4.73,   m22 = 4.62,   sd21 = 1.958,   sd22 = 2.12,   n21 = 66,   n22 = 58 )  # View the comparison: damisch_v_calinjageman_raw #>                       Estimate        SE         t          p          LL #> Original:                 1.67 0.7633058 2.1878519 0.03803154  0.09964253 #> Follow-up:                0.11 0.3682078 0.2987443 0.76566558 -0.61922358 #> Original - Follow-up:     1.56 0.8474743 1.8407638 0.07340024  0.13153488 #> Average:                  0.89 0.4237372 2.1003587 0.04232406  0.03245567 #>                              UL        df #> Original:             3.2403575  25.54543 #> Follow-up:            0.8392236 116.88772 #> Original - Follow-up: 2.9884651  38.36331 #> Average:              1.7475443  38.36331   # Now plot the comparison, focusing on the difference replicate.plot(damisch_v_calinjageman_raw, focus = "Difference")   # Plot the comparison, focusing on the average replicate.plot(damisch_v_calinjageman_raw,    focus = "Average",    reference_line = 0,   diamond_height = 0.1 )    # Kind of busy, but plot the comparison with both difference and average # In this case, store the plot for manipulation myplot <- replicate.plot(   damisch_v_calinjageman_raw,   focus = "Both",   reference_line = 0 )  # View the stored plot myplot   # Change x-labels and study labels myplot <- myplot + xlab("Difference in Putts Made, Lucky - Control") myplot <- myplot + scale_y_discrete(     labels = c(       "Average",       "Difference",       "Calin-Jageman & Caldwell, 2014",       "Damisch et al., 2010"       )   )    # View the updated plot myplot

title: vcmeta v1.0.1 (Release date: 2022/06/30)
text: Changes: Updated documentation several functions New functions standard errors: se.prop2, se.prop.ps New function chi-square test homegeniety: meta.chitest New function confidence interval average variance: meta.ave.var New functions replication studies: replicate.prop2, replicate.oddsratio, replicate.slope meta.lm.cronbach now takes (alpha, n, rel, r, X) rather (alpha, n, rel, q, X) se.cor now takes (cor, s, n) rather (cor, q, n) meta.sub.cronbach now takes (alpha, n, rel, r, group) rather (alpha, n, rel, q, group) meta.ave.cronbach now takes (alpha, n, rel, r, bystudy) rather (alpha, n, rel, q, bystudy)

title: vcmeta 1.0.0 (Release date: 2021/08/21)
